data.text: Taking a Dog on a Cycle Tour through Asia: Logistics?

Anyone who has cycled across Asia with a dog? I consider adopting one and bring it on my next trip. A lot of logistical questions comes to mind and I believe that someone in this group must have answers. Iâ€™m starting in Denmark and will mostly cycle in Middle East and Central Asia.
Hello, not a best ideas to Travel with animal, as some country like Vietnam, Cambodia. A lot of dog and caf are stolen, for meat trade.
data.author: Joeby Daff

data.text:
If you find s dog there, maybe possible but most hotels, even the $5-10 ones don't allow pets. The logistics to find places, and the likely higher cost, could be an annoying challenge to overcome. Wild camping is very hard in any SEA countries. Almost every inch of land is occupied or too wild to bush whack through. Again, not impossible, but more difficult than Europe or US regardless the legality. The biggest challenge will probably be dealing with all the paperwork and various vaccines and govt certificates and official stamps needed to bring a dog into x country. Some might require animal quarantine. Thailand reserves the right to hold your dog up to 30 days if they feel like it. They also want an itinerary of where your dog will be during your trip. Not sure "on a bike" will be accepted. Do a Google search for the countries you want to visit. Below is from the zrhsi embassy. It looks pretty intensive. Don't forget that your home country will also have there own rules https://canberra.thaiembassy.org/bringing-pets-into-thailand-2/
Bringing Pets into Thailand - Royal Thai Embassy Canberra
canberra.thaiembassy.org
data.author: Adir Sharon

data.text: Stupid idea, not fun and exhausting for a dog and dangerous for them. Some local dog pack will pop up in any street and give you hell. Why do people come up with such ideas? Like cycling thousands of miles with 2yo child and similar. Have some common sense, please...
data.author: Krzysztof Albinger

data.text: Going against the 'sense' of the masses does not mean one's intentions are wrong.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: do you have experience of this?
data.author: Nelson Incog Nito

data.text: well, intentions might be good but the very idea still wrong.
data.author: Krzysztof Albinger

data.text: do you necessarily need experience of pain of smashing head over the wall to know to not to do that? Taking a dog on a SHORT ride (in a basket or having the dog running after you) is ok, but not for a very long cycling travel.
data.author: Krzysztof Albinger

data.text: It's a terrible idea
data.author: Javier ColÃ³n

data.text: Well said! ðŸ˜‚ Iâ€™ve been on my first tour this week and seen a few dogs on bikes. Donâ€™t know how far they were going though
data.author: Nelson Incog Nito

data.text: I met a cyclist on my Americas tour in Panama whom had cycled from Alaska, heading to Ushuaia, where I had started, and seen several blogs with other's on extended tours with a dog. It's not factual, but only your opinion that makes it 'wrong'.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I didn't say it's impossible. If I did, then the fact that he made it, would invalidate what I said, didn't it? I said it's possibly bad and wrong for a dog. It's not like the dog can complain using human language, right? And even if it seemed happy, there are numerous dangers for him we can't objectively quantify. I'm just saying it is irresponsible idea in general. Some people with some dogs can make it happen. But as a principle, it's risky and kind of stupid. Dog will generally not appreciate traveling as we do. He sticks with us because he lives us. That doesn't invalidate my point.
data.author: Krzysztof Albinger

data.text:
I'd never said you said it was impossible. So far as the dog being unhappy, have a look at this animal, 'Nala', he's cycled all over with her after finding her at the road side. Now try telling me that cat isn't happy..... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uj0HAOKmRak&ab_channel=TheDodo
Guy Biking Across the World Picks Up a Stray Kitty | The Dodo Soulmates
youtube.com
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I am living at HCMC, Vietnam. It will easy, if You cross border of countries in Asia. But, Border of Myanmar does not open now because army closed border long time. My friend, he did not crossed from Nepal to Myanmar. Good blessing you and safe
data.author: David David

data.text: You cannot easily cross borders with a dog and it's not particularly fun or pleasant for a dog to constantly be in a trailer on a busy highway. Don't take any animals.
data.author: Javier ColÃ³n

data.text: I'm not really sure why this post was responded to so rudely. People regularly tour with children and animals and it's a great experience. It all depends on distance, terrain and if the individuals are enjoying the ride. I've known dogs that have been excited to hop into their spot and get on the road. Actually, I met one of my dogs (roadie) on a tour through the south U.S.- we had not intended to adopt any animals, but her situation was bad enough that she came with us. Since political borders are arbitrary and kindness shouldnt be- I'm also curious what cross border travel with a pup might look like
data.author: Julie Farris

data.text: Iâ€™m currently touring with my dog in Africa. Is it harder sometimes? Yes! But for me itâ€™s definitely worth it! And my furrbal loves to be with me and travel in his little trailer!
data.author: Anja Verschoor
Anja Verschoor

data.text: Borders could be fun. Although you could tell the guard that the dog just followed you for the last mile. However, you have to consider that if you then want to take the dog home with you, to maybe EU, US, Oz, there will be problems OR some would choose to just abandon the dog (somewhat cruel).
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Omni tierra channel on YouTube cycling around the world with dog
